subject: Re: [junit] Junit Report Generation using TestSuites
msgSnippet: Hi James, Thanks a lot for the help . I was thinking of modifying XMLJunitResultFormatter to do the job, since the generation of XML files is done using it. I
messageBody:
Hi James,

Thanks a lot for the help . I was thinking of modifying XMLJunitResultFormatter to do the job, since the generation of XML files is done using it. I will try out the option that you have suggested.
-Suganya



James Abley <james.abley@...> wrote:
On 19/08/05, suganya s <sugu_subramanian2581@...> wrote:
>
> Hi,
>
> The JUnit reports that I have been able to generate so
> far contain all test methods of testcases added on to
> the TestSuite displayed on the same page. i. e, Say If
> test1A(), test2A() methods belong to testcase A and
> test1B() and test2B() methods belong to testcase B.
> Now if I add testcases A and B to SampleTestSuite,
> then when I click on the link to SampleTestSuite, it
> displays test1A(), test2A(), test1B() and test2B(). Is
> there a way that I can get JUnit reports such that
> when I click on SampleTestSuite, I get the Link to
> testcases A and B, which in turn leads me to the
> results of test methods belonging to the corresponding
> testcases.
>
> This way I can easily partition the results of
> different testcases added onto a given testsuite.
>
> Thanks,
> Suganya Subramanian
>
>
>
> ____________________________________________________
>

Though not stated, I'm guessing you're using the ANT junit and junitreport
tasks. This has been discussed previously on the ant-user list.

http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?l=ant-user&m=110294136915617&w=2

The short answer is that it isn't supported. The longer answer is that you
can roll your own version, but you might need to patch junit to do it.

A sample patch to get you started is
here<http://sourceforge.net/tracker/index.php?func=detail&aid=1114925&group_id=15278&atid=315278>.
It was sufficient for my purposes at the time, but I eventually figured out
a way to do it using vanilla junit 3.8.1 and using a more complex TestRunner
in my ANT task.

I unfortunately can't include the ANT task - it's proprietary to my company
for the foreseeable time, but it was pretty straightforward to create a new
task and a custom formatter. From what I remember, the nasty part was the
XSLT to produce the html from the new hierarchical result xml.

Feel free to contact me off the list if you have any specific questions
about how to proceed further.

James
